questions.text: A 50 yrs female complaining of back pain and difficulty in bending down. She was advised MRI spine shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paget's disease Paget’s disease: vertebrae show cortical thickening of the superior plate and the inferior plate creates “picture frame” vertebrae. Diffuse radiodense enlargement of the vertebra is referred to as an ivory vertebra. In the above case, the vertebra shows radiodense deposition leading to the ivory vertebra.

Highyeild:

CLINICAL FEATURES: Pt is asymptomatic with elevated alkaline phosphatase enzymes. The skeletal sites most commonly involved are the pelvis, vertebral bodies, skull, femur and tibia. The most common presenting feature is pain, which may result from increased bony vascularity, expanding lytic lesions, fractures, and bowing. Bowing of the femur or tibia causes gait abnormality and mechanical stresses with secondary osteoarthritis of hip or knee joints. Long bone bowing also causes extremity pain by stretching the muscle attached to the bone softened extremity pain by stretching muscle attached to the bone softened by the pagetic process. Back pain results from enlarged pagetic vertebrae, vertebral compression fractures, spinal stenosis, degenerative changes of the joints and altered body mechanics with kyphosis and forward tilt of the upper back. Spinal cord compression may result from bone enlargement or vascular steal syndrome. Skull involvement may cause headaches, symmetric or asymmetric enlargement of the parietal or frontal bones and increased head size. Compression of the nerve due to narrow cranial nerve foramen causes neurological complications like hearing loss from cochlear nerve damage from temporal bone involvement, cranial palsies and softening of the base of the skull(platybasia) with a risk of brainstem compression. Paget’s disease can be diagnosed radiologically and with biochemical abnormalities. Radiography includes enlargement and expansion of the entire bone, the skull shows “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumcripta, thickening of diploic bone. vertebrae shows cortical thickening of the superior plate and the inferior plate creates “picture frame” vertebrae. Diffuse radiodense enlargement of the vertebra is referred to as an ivory vertebra. Alkaline phosphatase is increased and is a test of choice in some cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Rickets:The radiodense verterbra is not the feature of rickets. Option: C. Osteoporosis: it is characterized by a sclerotic lesion of the vertebra and leads to fractures.

Extraedge:

Treatment: The treatment of Paget’s disease includes: 1. bisphosphonates like zoledronic acid, pamidronate, risedronate and alendronate. 2. calcitonin.

questions.text: A 60 yrs female was diagnosed with Paget's disease. Which of the following is the phase of the disease that can be observed in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: An initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization

options.label: B
options.text: The second phase is a period of very active bone formation and resorption that replace the normal lamellar bone with haphazard woven bone

options.label: C
options.text: In the final sclerotic phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget's disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . An initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization : It is stage one of Paget’s disease. Option: B. The second phase is a period of very active bone formation and resorption that replaces normal lamellar bone with haphazard woven bone : It is stage two of Paget’s disease.
